Replies.Reply: Maggio walking across the yard flanked by the tall MPs. He looks around as if surveying the chances of escape. Music rises.
Framed beautifully in the moonlight, the Quadrangle and Barracks area look like a college campus. Silence. No movement.
Several groups of two and three scattered about. They are standing in no particular places, as if they have been walking and stopped suddenly. They are all looking toward the Bugler.
The taxi pulls up across the street from camera. A soldier gets out, pulls two heavily loaded barracks bags after him.

A small thin soldier in an undershirt and fatigue pants backs out of the screen door and into shot. He is wielding a frayed broom. This is PRIVATE ANGELO MAGGIO. He is violent and funny and sour and friendly. He sees Prewitt's legs but not his face, speaks as he sweeps a cloud of dust off the porch.
The Dayroom has a pool table, ping-pong table, a radio, etc.
as Prew and Warden enter. Maggio is sweeping the room.
During this shot Maggio can be seen in b.g. through door to Orderly Room. He pretends to be sweeping, but stops now and then to listen.
as Prew and Warden enter and walk through. Maggio bobs his head approvingly at Prew.
as Warden jumps in. He takes off his rain hat.
The kitchen is small and undistinguished. Karen takes a whisky bottle from a cabinet, pours a straight, stiff drink, puts it on the sink. Warden puts the papers down and drinks.

The bugle is heard over shot. A line of spruced-up men stretches through the mess hall. A blanket is spread over a table and behind it sits Holmes, flanked by Warden and Mazzioli. In front of Holmes is a pile of greenbacks and a cigar box filled with silver. He is paying out the man at the head of the line.

as Prew enters behind Mrs. Kipfer. The vestibule has an old South feeling of mustiness and respectability. Maggio is handing some bills to ANNETTE, a young, brash-looking girl, who sits behind a reception desk.

Prew and Galovitch are standing in front of the Captain's desk. Prew is at attention, the heavy pack on his back; his face is drawn and tired; his clothes are plastered to him. He has regained his old expressionless look. Warden has swung his chair around and is surveying the scene. Holmes looks 66.
Prew and a group of G Company men, including Sergeants Dhom, Thornhill and Henderson, are on the steps and porch as a Reconnaissance car pulls up and halts.
as the Recon pulls out and Maggio's last hearty shout drifts back.
as the MPs march Maggio up to a door and gesture him to enter alone. He goes in.
The small house is perched precariously on the very edge of the cliff. Alma and Prew come around the bend, come up to the door, Prew marvelling at the house.

The porch is at the rear of the house, leading off from the living room. It is on the very edge of the cliff. Prew and Alma are dancing to the music of a portable victrola. It is playing "Why Don't We Do This More Often?" A table still contains the dinner plates. Prew's expression holds the wonder of a child at a magic show. He misses a step, stumbles.
Holmes, seeing Prew is now clearly in command, steps out of the crowd and up to the two fighters.
Holmes pulls himself together, turns to the crowd.
Three men come out of the barracks, lean over the porch rail, listening. Their faces are thoughtful, sad.
There are eight or nine men here now, listening.
A half dozen men are sitting on the steps, listening, among them Stark and Wilson. Stark shakes his head sadly.

Fatso is on his back, his stomach gushing bloods his eyes already glazing. Prew staggers into the light now. His left side has two vicious cuts; he is bleeding badly. He stares down at Fatso, who manages a small, reproving voice.
Prew comes toward camera, laboriously struggling up the road.

FEATURING Warden at the NCO table. He rises, carries his plate with him towards the chow line. A sudden, deep-toned, earthquake-like blast shudders through the room. The cups on the tables rattle. Warden stops, cocks his head. The men stop eating, look at each other.
Some of the men continue to crane at the sky. A few pick up metal links from the Jap bullets.

The men rush for cover, all except Choate who is left alone in shot. He takes a big bite of his sausage and eggs, hastily downs a swig of coffee. Then he throws the plate and cup into the street and dives for cover as the terrifyingly loud noise of the Jap planes indicates they are directly overhead.
The non-coma are arguing violently with Leva at the door to the Supply Room. Jap planes are loud overhead.
as Warden runs in. Broken glass lies all over the floor.
as the men on the roof reload. In the distance the Jap planes have turned and are heading back for the roof.
Prew rises, staggers away from the jeep.
Fine way to pass the time. Good for the mind.

enlistment Blues'!

You heard me! This ain't no maneuvers. You go runnin around outside you'll get your ears shot off. You want to be heroes, you'll get plenty chances later. You'll probly have Japs in your laps before night.

You stick in the kitchen and make a big pot of coffee. No -- make a barrel of coffee.
Whatever you say, Pete.
Gimme them keys!
What's the matter? You blind? You see them planes --?!
Okay. Chief, bust the door down.
Get the hell out of the way!
Go ahead. Bust it down. He'll get out of the way.
Okay. I'll see you get a medal.
You'll catch a cold, Turp.
You better put your pants on.
-- Don't worry about wasting ammo!

He's at Headquarters, sir. I'm the First Sergeant.
Yes, sir.
Yes, sir.
It's the mouthpiece of a bugle.

Thank you, sir.
as Prew and Warden walk along the porch, Warden a few paces ahead. They go into the Orderly Room.
Those medics didn't get the Sickbook back till late yesterday --
Private Prewitt, thirty dollars base pay. Deductions-laundry, insurance, PX checks.

At ease. Good morning, men.

At ease.

Plenty of room for advancement for a man who knows how to soldier. But he's got to show me he's got it on the ball. I don't know what you've been used to in the Bugle Corps, but in my outfit we run it by the book. What kind of trouble were you in over there?
What made you transfer out, then?
Something you wanted to ask, Sergeant?
Well, we'll get your stripes back for you, maybe an extra one for good measure. You know why you were sent over here when you requested transfer?
My Regiment got beaten last year in the finals, as you know.
But I mean to win this year. And I will. All I've needed was a top middleweight.
Next year I'll hang your picture up there with the others, my boy.
Yes, it's too bad about that. I can understand how you feel. But those things happen in this game. A man has got to accept that possibility when he fights.
it this way. What if all fighters felt like that?
Would you have us disband our fighting program because one man got hurt?
You might as well say stop war because one man got killed. Our fighting program is the best morale builder we have off here away from home.

It looks to me like you're trying to acquire a reputation as a lone wolf, Prewitt. You should know that in the Army it's not the individual that counts. If a man wants to get ahead he has certain responsibilities to fulfill that go beyond the regulations. It might look as though I were a free agent, but I'm not. Nobody is.
Maybe you'll change your mind. In the meantime just don't make any mistakes in my outfit.
I've got to go into town. Is there anything else for me today, Sergeant?
You make it out. Is that all?
Well, whatever it is, you fix it.
I'm sorry I'm so late. And about dinner, I --
-- I got tied up with General Slater. Bumped into him at the Officers' Club.
I had some business to attend to in town. During the afternoon.
Now what does that mean?
How many, times do I have to tell you I haven't any other women before you'll believe me?
That again. How long will it be, I wonder, before I'm allowed to live that down? After eight years, how many times do I have to tell you It Was An Accident?
I didn't say that. I know what it's done to you, but --
I won't be back in time to take Retreat.
Or Reveille either, probably.
All work and no play, Sergeant. All you do is sit around sweating over this paper and that. There are other things in this world beside work.
You ought to get out more yourself, Warden.
Well, I'm going.
I'm leaving it in your care, Sergeant.
-- this man Prewitt's been here over a month now. I expected you mend have him around before this.
Maybe he needs a good dose of The Treatment.
You understand. I don't want any rough stuff.
But we all know good athletes make good leaders. And good leaders --
-- and just see you don't drink all this up in one place.
Have you given any thought to the boxing team recently, Prewitt?
What's this man's pay?
What's the matter with you, Prewitt? You know better than to talk back to a non-commissioned officer.
I think you owe Sergeant Galovitch an apology.
Sergeant Galovitch, take this man to the barracks and have him roll a full field pack, extra shoes, helmet and all, and then take a bicycle and hike him up to Kole-
I take it you're ready to apologize to Sergeant Galovitch now.
Take him back up there again, Galovitch. He hasn't had enough yet.
1 know that kind of man! He's an againster. A bitter-ender. You can't be decent to a man like that.
Why? Do you see any other way of breaking him?
All right, all right. But throw the book at him.
-- I've known about it for a long time! I've sensed it. And I'm not going to ignore it any longer! I want to know where you met him and just who he is.
One thing I know. I know it's a civilian. You'd be too discreet to pick an Army man.
It is my business! I'm your husband! What do you think a scandal would do to my chances for a promotion? So if you're thinking of a divorce, you can forget it!
Now -- how does it feel to know you'll have to live with a horror like me the rest of your life?
You don't know how a man feels about a thing like this. It breaks a man all up -- inside.
It's -- it's just not the same.
Tried to be a Company Commander when I hate it, worked my fool head off with this miserable boxing squad, tagged after the General whenever I could.
Why, for you and for me. For our home, that's why.
At ease, Sergeant. What's the matter?
There's no rush. I'll take care of it.
All right. Let's cut it.
What started this?
You won't disobey any more orders in my Company, Prewitt. Warden saved you from a court martial once but he won't this time --
Thornhill, you're in charge of this detail. How about it?
That's all. Break it off. Let's get back to our jobs.
--- that's right, it's a letter of resignations I'm through! I've already been relieved! So you can begin packing. We're sailing for the States next week!
Sir, Private Robert E. Lee Prewitt reporting to the Compny Commander as ordered.
Or was it just because you couldn't stand to bugle?

I pulled a few strings. I'm the Regimental Boxing Coach, Prewitt. I saw your fight with Connors in the Bowl year before last. With any luck you should have won it. I thought for a while, in the second round, you were going to knock him out.
The Company takes care of itself.
I'm willing to forgive you. Tell me who he is. Make a clean breast of it. And I'll forgive you.
wretched, completely at a loss. He stares into space, then looks down at his food, picks up a fork and ruefully begins to eat.
You mean that fallow you hurt --
Prew's lips are drawn tight. He nods almost imperceptibly.
working over the sink.
warmed by the friendliness of the music and the moment.
astonished yet appreciative that under Warden's confidence and control in Choy's there has been a human frailty.
heartsick as he looks at Maggio.
A fear, not born of cowardice, is reflected on Prew's face as he sets himself, stares at Galovitch. He seems haunted by the memory of Dixie Wells.
staring down at Maggio.
continuing the Taps. There are tears in his eyes now.
He smiles faintly, holds the glass high.

looking toward the jeep, blinded by the blazing light. He has the appearance of a terrified animal. There is a wildness, a senselessness about him. The blotch of blood oozes and spreads over his shirt. He picks up a rock from the road.
as they come out of the Orderly Room. Prew hoists his barracks bags to his shoulders, balancing them delicately.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM SHOT SHOOTING INTO SUPPLY ROOM

Replies.Reply: SUPPLY SERGEANT LEVA is eating a candy bar with one hand and leisurely typing up a form with the other. He is a foolish-
I can't do no better on what you people pay me.
Her and them sweaters.
But man, she sure is one, ain't she?
One woman.
I'm tellin you, Top, she's trouble.
Any word on Maggio's Court Martial?
He'll get the Stockade sure.
Can't a man rest himself for a min--
Yes, sir.
I don't care. I can't issue any live ammunition without a signed order from an officer.
I'm sorry fellows. Lieutenant Ross give me them orders himself. No signed order, no ammo. And that's all they are to it.
I ain't gonna do it, Top. I --
Remember I warned you. I did my best.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT WARDEN AND LEVA

Replies.Reply: watching Karen. Leva leans over the counter.
Good morning, Sergeant.
I'm looking for my husband.
Oh. Of course, He was to have left some things for me.
That he was to have purchased. Do you know anything about them?
He's been telling me quite a bit about you lately. My husband. He says you're very efficient.
What is it that makes you so efficient, Sergeant?
I love that. Well, good-bye, Sergeant.
It doesn't matter.
Yes? What did the General have to say?
If you'd spend less time buttering Generals and more time with your Company, maybe you'd get that promotion.
I went over there this morning looking for you.
From the way you look I gather your business wasn't too successful.
Dana. Give me credit for a few brains.
What right?
That makes it all right, I suppose!
You know I hate to talk about it!
You had a way of knowing, Dana. I want to go to bed. Please get out of my bedroom.
Oh. If it isn't Sergeant Warden.
If you're looking for my husband, he isn't here.
He still isn't here. If that does you any good.
I haven't the slightest idea.
I'll try phoning him at the Club for you.
What is it you want, Sergeant?
You're taking an awful chance, you know. My maid is liable to be home any time.
You think of everything, don't you, Sergeant?
Are these really important?
Replies.Didascalie: (goes to sink, picks up THE PAPERS)

Replies.Reply: That's what I like about you, Sergeant. You have confidence. It's also what I dislike about you.
Honesty? How did you acquire such an old-fashioned virtue?
Well, he's clever as well as virile.
Not if I can help it.
What are you doing?
I don't know, Sergeant. To be honest, I don't know.
You don't have to spend money on me, Sergeant.
Maybe.
Why, hello. I didn't think you were coming.
No, I guess you're not. But then I came a little early. I must have been overanxious. You weren't overanxious though, were you? You got here right on the dot.
You certainly chose a savory spot for our meeting.
No, but I've had five chances to be picked up in the last few minutes.
Well, I don't care for it. I never went in much for back-alley loving.
You probably think I'm a tramp, don't you?
Don't try to be gallant, Sergeant.
On the other hand, I've got a bathing suit under my dress.
I hope the ocean's ice cold. I hope I freeze in a solid chunk.
I love the way you laugh.
No. Nobody.
Well, that will take some figuring.
Not without an adding machine. Do you have your adding machine with you?
Then I guess you won't find out, will you?
What's the matter? What are you hinting at?
I don't know. Maybe a lot. Or maybe you just think there's a lot.
You must be crazy -- !
I had to go and forget you were a man -- with the same rotten filthy mind the rest of them have. For a minute I had to convince myself you were different --
Yes, it's true! A part of it, some small part of whatever sewage you've been listening to. Some day perhaps you'll get all the story.
You're getting to sound so much like a typical male. So you just sweat it out like a typical male.
All right. I've never told it to anyone before. But I think now is the time. I'll tell you the whole bloody messy thing. You can take it back to the barracks with you.
I'd been married to Captain Dana E.
And, of course, one more thing no more children. Do you know what that means? You're not a woman.
All right. I'm listening.
I know. Until I met you I didn't think it was possible, either.
You just love to shock people, don't you?! Where on earth did you learn to dance like that?
What did she say?
It can't go on like this much longer, Milt.
There is a way. I've been thinking about it.
You've got to become an officer.
You're eligible for the extension course that came in with the draft.
Then I could divorce Dana and follow you and marry you.
That's a fine, intelligent point of view. Suppose I said I've always hated Sergeants. That would make a lot of sense, wouldn't it?
You can't be certain of that --
Why don't you tell the truth?
You just don't want the responsibility. You're probably not even in love with me --
I don't know what's happened to you -- you were honest at first --
And so they were married and lived unhappily ever after.
Neither have I.
Neither would I.
You'll make a fine officer. A remarkable officer.
I'm afraid I'm not going to tell you.
I'm not going to hide anything. I'm just not going to tell you.
I don't think it's any of your business who he is.
Not very nice. But then there's the compensation of knowing you'll have to live with me the rest of your life.
I gander why men feel so differently about it than women.
Done all what?
I don't know. Why?
I always thought you did it because you wanted to get ahead.
It's a lovely day out. I think I'll go for a walk.
I wonder which is hurt more -- your pride or your curiosity?
When I'm ready to ask you for a divorce we can discuss it again.
And do eat your breakfast, Dana.
I guess I knew deep down you wouldn't do it. But --
Well, here we are saying goodbye.
I'm going back with him, Milt.
That sounds like Milt Warden, all right.
No, Milt. I don't want to kiss you any more. I just want to remember you. And you to remember me.
I think It's the most beautiful place I ever saw in my lire.
There's a legend. If they float in toward shore, you'll come back some day. If they float out to sea, you won't.
Oh, I am sorry.
That's very fine of her.
Who?
If it were so, don't you think I'd admit it? The way things are between us now? What right have you to always be accusing me?
as Alma comes over to Prew.
How many times do I have to tell you I'm sorry, about that? How many times that I had no way of knowing -

The room is fairly well filled with soldiers. The click of pool balls is heard over shot. Warden is reading a newspaper.. A column heading, conspicuous in shot, reads: JAPS ADVANCE IN CHINA. Warden drops the paper on his lap, looks toward pool table, squinting thoughtfully.
His laughter now also diminished to a happy grin as he dances. In all he dances about thirty seconds. Then he breaks out of the group and runs over to Karen.

The office lit only by a light over his desk. He is working late, a sheaf of papers spread out before him. He listens to the bugle call, moved, sorrowful. He snaps off the light, listens in the darkness.
Maggio, Prew and CHIEF CHOATE, a Corporal, are playing pool.
I'm coldern a Idaho winter tonight.
You might as well get use to it, kid. You probly be seein it often before you die.

Top, you sure plastered.
Them engineers mighty ambitious Sunday mornin before eight o'clock.
Hats got it locked up. An the keys in his pocket.

him, sir.

A double dose needs him to be given.
Clean up dis mess, Prewitt!

Clean up, Prewitt!
How? What!
What!
Yes, Sirr.
Move along. You not half way yet.
Top of pass, Sir. This man insubordinate. The Captain is teaching him lesson.
Company G, 219th, Sir.
Yes, air.
Still on knees, eh, Prewitt? Well, boxing finals next month. December f if teen. You s till got time help us make champions.
You need better lesson than up to now. Maybe I give to you myself.
Prewitt talk back to non-com.
guy.
You heard him. Better think it over.
-- rifle's your beat friend. In case them weapons jams in combat could mean life or death. You got to know 'em inside out. Now I want you to strip them weapons and put it together again.
Go!
Your rear sight's way off! You'd be fifty feet off your target at three hundred yards!
That's what comes when a soljer don't know how to assemble a rifle.
You better get down to the track and carry it around a few times.
We've been runnin him pretty hard.
No, sir, this wasn't Prewitt's fault.
But there ain't no officers yet, you jerk! Lieutenant Ross lives off the post.
You want a busted head, Maggio?
Then keep your big nose out altogether.
Trainin season starts next week --
Okay, Prewitt. No halts barred.
Prewitt! Step out!
You march like a drunk gooney bird!
He blinded a guy once. Must be scairt of the same thing.
That's right, sir. Everybody knows Galovitch started it.
Yeah. An come over to Choy's tonight. We buy you a beer.
He won't let us have no ammo, Top!
Come on, you dirty sons --
His paper still on his lap. He has been watching. He wears a faint smile of respect.

standing on the open porch, in the rain. He wears a GI raincoat. He is squinting at the door with the same expression he used looking at Karen's picture. He takes a deep breath as if he were going off a high diving board, then knocks briskly. A shadow moves across the room behind the curtains. Then Karen opens the door. She is in shorts and a blouse.

protesting, joining in the laughter. Suddenly he kicks off his shoes, rolls his slacks up to his knees. He snatches a gardenia from the hair of a pretty Hawaiian girl next to him, sticks it over his ear, jumps into the firelight and dances with the others. The music comes up louder and faster as the spectators and dancers roar.

He stares at the picture, then looks at the application blank. Then he looks down at the chevrons on his arm. He rubs his hand over the chevrons gently, fondly. He looks at the application blank again very thoughtfully.
listening now on the porch alongside the street.
firing the BAR, standing, as the Jap planes roar over. He staggers back from the recoil.

In b.g. a few of the men are moving to and from the latrine but most of them are in their bunks. Over shot the sound of a bugle blowing Tattoo is heard. Lights are being extinguished in various parts of the room. Prew and Choate are lying on adjoining bunks, smoking. Choate's voice is almost linked to his last speech of preceding scene.

carrying rifles, marching at attention. Prew is FEATURED in shot; a light smile of pleasure as he moves along. Choate, bringing up the rear, is singing the Regimental Marching Song in a wonderful basso. Dhom marches on one side of the platoon, Galovitch on the other. Dhom calls out the "huts."

Characters.Character: CLOSE SHOT FEET OF MEN MARCHING

Replies.Reply: They are in perfect unison.
DHOM'S VOICE Prewitt! Get in step, Prewitt!

kneeling over their rifles, laid out on shelter halves. Prew is FEATURED in shot. His shirt is wet and he is sweating heavily, as if he has just come from the run around the track. Henderson stands in front of the group, instructing.
stripping rifles. Prew is efficient and brilliantly fast, Maggio fumbling and slow. Maggio keeps looking over at Prew, admiring his speed.
toiling around track together, holding rifles.
running around track to sun, rifle held before him. The smile is fainter but still there.

bent over the sink, scraping, washing and rinsing cooking pans and mixing basins. He hangs the soap bucket on the hot faucet and turns it on full force. As he does, PRIVATE WILLARD, a fat, whining cook, dumps an additional huge pile of pans before him. Prew looks at them ruefully. Willard says something to him with a "hustle up" gesture. The faucet drowns the words.
He is in fatigue clothes, on his knees, scrubbing the floor.

is droning out an account of Pearl Harbor. Prew, still on the couch in his pajamas, looks as if he has just struggled to wakefulness. He listens to the radio for a few moments in confused disbelief. He shakes his head vigorously as if to throw off his grogginess. He shakes his head again, slowly, more knowingly now, nodding as if he remembers something from the broadcast of the morning. Then as if all of it hits him suddenly and fully and terribly he wrenches himself off the couch. He looks around at the dimly lit room.

standing on the lip of the trap, the jeep bearing down on him. He turns, starts to dive into the trap. A blast of gunfire from the jeep hits him. He falls sideways into the trap, rolls over on his back, The jeep moves into the shot, crawls half-way over the trap, stops, its spotlight pouring down on Prew. His eyes are open, looking up to the sky.

The platoon is divided into teams of two. Thornhill is the instructor. This is actual hand-to-hand training. Prew wields his rifle, bayonet fixed, in expert thrusts. Maggio is fighting in next lane. Thornhill walks behind Prew, trips him quickly as he passes. Prew falls off balance. His opponent smashes his rifle against Prew's, knocks it to the ground.
as he turns to watch the departing car.
It is a gloomy, rainy day and the lights are on in the office. Warden is at his desk, working. Holmes is buckling on his trench coat. He wears a happy smile.
Holmes slams his fist on his desk.

Characters.Character: FLASHES GALOVITCH WILSON DHOM THORNHILL HENDERSON

Replies.Reply: riding Prew, mocking him, grinning at him, thumbing him to the track, etc. FEATURED is Galovitch, who takes particular Joy in baiting Prew.
running around track, staggering despite a tremendous effort not to show his fatigue.
chinning himself on bar setup near obstacle course; he is near physical exhaustion.

with the platoon going through, crouched low, live ammunition spattering around them. Prew, nearest camera, is lower than any man in the line. Over shot we hear a snatch of Wilson's Voice yelling at Prew to get lower.
Wilson bawling Prew out, thumbing him to one side of obstacle course.
going through alone, on his belly in deep mud.

The Mesa Sergeant, a tall, gaunt man, surveys the scene possessively. Maggio, Dining Room Orderly today, wearing a soiled white coat, flashes by to the mess hall, almost dropping his loaded tray in his haste.

A slow, lazy, heavy man, peeling potatoes. There is a large kettle filled with dirty water in front of him in which the potatoes are floating. Treadwell stabs at one with a long fork, misses it. He stabs again, almost in slow motion, misses again. He sees Stark glowering over him.
rifle man, not a spud-cutter.
Man, that's blues! Where'd you drag that one up Prom?
I bet I got two hundred blues records back home.
Hey, what about me? I been waitin all my life to git to shoot a BAR at somethin!
Friday's gone crazy! He's blowing the Cavalry Charge!
Rifle man, huh? All somebody'd have to do would be holler war at you and it'd be over the hill and far away.
Hole up 'at noise. This man's hot as a forty-five shootin downhill.
I think you're a fat cook who can't cook.
This ain't no rassle, Ike. You got to fight this man fair.
Whatsa matter with you, you crazy, dumb screwballs?! You tryin to get killed?!
I borrowed it. I'm goin to town.
Your friend, huh?
You both must be plumb nuts.
I guess I'm the one who's nuts.
Fatso's lucky. They'll figure he got killed fallin out of that truck.
I'll take him, Prew.
What you want me to do, First? I got a hangover, but I can still --

The faucet is still on and we cannot hear what Willard says as he dumps more pans before Prew. However, he is obviously complaining that Prew is slow. Prew, sweating and angry, barks something back at him and turns the faucet off.

All I ask is that you keep the pans washed up so they're clean when I need them. In order that I am allowed to cook the kind of food required for men who work hard all day and who need good nourishing food to get their nourishment.
How you think I can do my job if the Mess Sergeant takes sides with a goldbricking KP? What do you think I am?

Characters.Character: MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT PREW AND WARDEN

Replies.Reply: Warden looking at Prew's hand. Warden's grin broadens with something more than sarcasm. He is 'impressed and pleased by Prew's honest anger.
He is blowing the bugle, sounding Pay Call. The rays of a blinding sun flash on its shiny surface.

Payday night. A gay, noisy jamboree. Soldiers, mostly in civilian clothes, and uniformed sailors swarm down the street. Taxi drivers arguing with their fares as they pull up at bars. Filipinos padding in twos and threes.

Raucous, hammering music sweeps away the melancholy blues. On the floor of the gym Dhom is punching the bag. In a corner of the raised ring Ike Galovitch is skipping rope. In the center of the ring Thornhill and Henderson are sparring. Holmes hovers beside them, issuing instructions in a strident voice.

Prew stops on the threshold, stares at the room in happy amazement. It is large, smartly furnished. In the rear, glass doors lead to a porch. One of the panelled walls is filled with bookshelves, floor to ceiling. The bookshelves are filled with books. A hearty feminine voice calls "Hi!" from the kitchen, and as Prew and Alma come into the room, GORGETTE enters from the kitchen. She is a very tall, very gay, good-looking girl.
SHOOTING through smoke rising from one of the trench-ovens.
Most of the men turn in their beds toward the sound of the bugle. Some prop up on their elbows.
More men are propped on their elbows, their heads turned toward the Bugler. The dim figure of Treadwell can be seen, at a window now.
The men are pouring in from the Company street, all shouting at once. Warden pushes his way through them and jumps up on the pool table. His big voice booms.

The Jap strafing attack is continuing. Their planes are making a figure 8 in the sky. Silhouettes of men on the roof can b e seen. Friday Clark is blowing his Cavalry Charge. In b.g. men of the loading detail are scurrying around.

As before, pandemonium -- but controlled and efficient. The men are hoarse from shouting, red-eyed, puffing from excitement and exertion. Two Jap planes swoop past and the full-throated umbrella of fire lets loose. Lieutenant Ross clambers onto the roof, stooping under the burden of the BAR and loading clips. The men greet him with a concerted cheer.

Maggio and Prew, dressed in slacks and Aloha shirts, stand in front of what looks like a renovated residence. They give evidence of having already accomplished a little substantial drinking. The sound of loud piano playing is heard from within. A sign over the door reads: NEW CONGRESS CLUB - SOFT DRINKS - DANCING - RECREATION - MEMBERS ONLY. The door opens 39.
Hearty male laughter from within. The door opens and Fatso and a couple of sailors cane out. They are about to start down the street.
It'll be eight bucks, Babyface.

Members are entitled to all privileges of the club which includes dancing, snack bar, soft drink bar, and gentlemanly relaxation with the opposite gender so long as they are gentlemen and no hard liquor is permitted.
Got it?
Don't tell me the Princess is your style.
Meet Suzanne and Roxanne.
Much as I adore your company, you must allow me to tear myself away.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM SHOT NEAR CURTAINS TO VESTIBULE

Replies.Reply: Maggio is attempting some serious dancing with SANDRA, a very tall girl. Fatso's furious tempo and tune keep drowning the langorous tango coming from the jukebox. Maggio keeps switching his style as he tries to get out of the range of the piano but cannot. He is very annoyed. He and Sandra dance out of shot, as Prew and Annette enter from the vestibule.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM SHOT FEATURING PREW AND ANNETTE

smiling back. Her head tilts up slowly as if someone is coming toward her. Prew comes into shot and stands before her, tongue-tied. She pats the couch. Her voice is low-
Would you like to sit down?

I haven't seen you in here before.
Oh. Somehow I didn't think you were a soldier.

Surely.
Bill here was telling me about surfboarding.
Sit down and just listen. He describes it thrillingly.

Shall we go, then?
That was a terrible way to have acted. What you did.
You're a funny one.
Now, look here, what do you think Mrs. Kipfer pays us for? We're hired to be nice to all the boys.
That piano is about to drive me out of my mind. Let's go up to Mrs.
No, I'm not mad.
You certainly are a funny one.
I had a boy friend. I was a waitress. He was from the richest family in town. He just married the girl suitable for his position.

So I left and went to Seattle, as a waitress. And I met a girl just back from Hawaii. She said she'd made a lot of money working for Mrs. Kipfer. I caught the first boat. I've been here a year and two months.
Oh, I don't like it. But I don't mind it. Anyway, I won't be here forever.
I have it all figured out. In another year I'll be back home, with a pile of bills big enough to choke a steer. And then I will be all set for life --
No, thanks. I never drink much.
I think it' a a weakness.
And I don't like weakness.
With you it's not a weakness. With you it's more like a virtue.
Well, it's so.
What's he mean, The Treatment?
What did he mean?
Fight?
My name's Alma.
where two men are holding Fatso and three girls are restraining Maggio. The others are amused by the quarrel, but Fatso and Maggio are deadly serious.
You're the kind of character I eat for breakfast, ya little --
Little Mussolini here tryin to tell me what way to play the piano.
Who's that? Who's that dame?
Whoever! Say, she's a real good piece of whistle bait! I'd sure like to get my mitts around her.
Why, holy -- I You hit met You hit me!
What?! But what for? That's no way to fight!
Why, you dirty yellow sneaking --
Replies.Didascalie: (reaches hand to head, brings away blood)

Replies.Reply: I'm gonna cut this little Wop's heart out. Anybody steps in here, I give it to him first.
Look outs here, Warden. This a private affair.
Tough monkey. Hard sister. Guys like you get to the Stockade sooner later. One day you walk in there I'll be waitin. I'll show you a coupla things.
Tough monkey.
Hard sister.
You want me?
I don't like that nickname. You want to see me about somethin?
Okay. Good night, gents.
Okay. You sore about somethin?
The little Wop? The one who bust out of the Stockade? Sure. He was a real tough monkey. But crazy, see?
Did I? If I did, he ask for it.
You've killed me. Why'd you want to kill me?

Characters.Character: MEDIUM SHOT AT SIDE OF ROOM

Replies.Reply: where Prew hauls Maggio away from the piano.
You know who that guy is, buddy?
Fatso Judson. Sergeant of the Guard at the Post Stockade.
-- I'm tellin you, leave him be.
What if they bomb us?
settling down at the piano again. He glances over in direction of Maggio with a mean smile. Then he starts to hammer the keys viciously.
as the music starts, Maggio stiffens, turns as if to go back.
All right, bully boy, now you won the war, let's dance.
-- you go along as fast as forty miles per through that surf and your balance has got to be letter perfect.
Hello, friend.
You know anything about surfboarding?
You must be stationed inland then.
A little bit. Are you a mountain climber?
I've had a few lessons.
Sure. The air in here seems to have gotten very smelly, hasn't it?
Listen, fellow --
He settles lower in the couch, the picture of frustration and hopelessness. He pulls a cigarette from his pocket and lights it.
Horrified, he starts toward the fracas.
working with his thoughts, afraid to broach them. He lights a cigarette, his fingers trembling.
looking up at Galovitch.
at the Bugler's post. He is finishing the last phrases, full and wonderful. Behind him stands Friday Clark, motionless.
Karen sits on the bench, her ankles crosses primly, very ill at ease. There is Payday activity here also; amorous strolling couples; men in ones and twos looking for pickups.

Fatso's piano music o.s. Prew is slumped on the couch. He stubs out the cigarette, which is almost burnt down. He sees someone coming toward him, slowly raises his eyes. Lorene comes into shot, looks down at him.
sweeping over camera, spray flying.
near shore, as Karen dives into it. Warden follows her. The wave washes over them.

A tiny beach set among rocks. The pale sand glows in the moonlight. Warden, in a bathing suit, is lighting a fire about ten yards from the water's edge. Karen is just stepping out of her dress; her bathing suit is underneath. A couple of GI blankets near the fire. Her teeth are beginning to chatter in the chill of the night air; she raises her arms to the sky longingly, happily.

as it opens slowly and a disembodied arm pokes through, its hand gripping the neck of a whisky bottle. After a moment, Maggio's head follows the arm through the door. He is grinning like an amateur conspirator.
as Maggio comes into the room.
as they kiss. The embrace is impassioned. When their lips separate, their arms remain around each other, holding tight to something they find is more than sex alone.
as Karen and Warden kiss again, a tenderness in him not seen before and which he normally takes great pains to hide.
The Profession wears you down, though, young man. Down thin like a knife what's been honed and honed.
Oh, sure. I could be Chief of Staff, too, except I can't stand leaving all my old buddies.
To take my stinkin shower, if the First Sergeant's got no objections.
Okay, Okay.
The Canal Zone for me. This girl down there. She was a planter's daughter, see. She lived a very sheltered life. A very moral young lady, Milt. I took her out to a high class dinner and then dancing.
Well, what did you expect? I was in a different mood, then.
I think I could get one of them Japs with a machine gun, Milt.
Nuts! Led him too tar.
Ah, nobody'll ever know which of us got that guy.
Oh, just stumbled on it.
'More dough than I can use. Re-
Sir -- I'm sorry, sir but Private Prewitt's not to blame for this.
Where you go in?
Must be dynamitin down to Wheeler Field.
as Anderson repeats a theme he has happened on. It has a haunting melody.
The other men have stopped weeding, are looking over at Prew and Galovitch. Thornhill, in b.g., puts down the comic book and comes over to them during following.
Some day I'm goin back to Scranton and play it for my folks. And tell em it wan composed in the Hawaiian Islands! Clear across the Pacific Ocean!
Yeah?
Don't know. I was borned on Wednesday.
Dead? But he was here just a minute ago.
'More dough than I can use. Re-
There are two water buckets near Galovitch. He skips near one of them, kicks it. The bucket falls on its side and dirty water spills over the ring and down onto Prew.
Prew is hunched under the seventy-pound pack as he plods along. He is sweat-soaked, puffing, dog-weary. Galovitch's bicycle is just behind him; he runs the wheels up on Prew's heels.

An aged Chinese, at least seventy-five, OLD CHOY has a long white beard and wears a black skull cap and an embroidered robe. He is motionless, surveying the pandemonium which we hear over shot: the sounds of men laughing, talking and shouting blend with jukebox music blasting Chattanooga, Choo Choo. YOUNG CHOP, Old Choy's son, passes; he is thirty, white-
reacting. He frowns, moved by the cry behind the music.
leaning against the building, undergoing a delayed reaction to the fierce moment in Choy's. He is white-faced, sweating heavily. He looks as if he's going to be sick.
He sits, thinks it over unhappily.

He has a hunch about this now. He reaches out to put his plate down, holding it very carefully in both hands. However, he doesn't bother to see if there is anything under it. The plate falls and crashes on the floor a fraction of a second before the third groundswell of blast shakes the room.
The room is quiet for several moments, except for the continuing jukebox music, which sounds pale and thin now.
Fatso turns toward Maggio, who circles back around the table as the other stalks him.
Lorene is covering Prew with sand and has him almost completely buried. Only his face remains uncovered. He is griming up at her. She seems thoughtful.
You must hate the Army.
Sure. Look what it's doing to you.
Love it? Well, it sure doesn't love you in return.
Yes, but a person can stand just so much from something --
A bugle?
You like him, don't you?
You better go look out for him,  Prew glances at her gratefully, then slips off his stool. He picks up Maggio's tie and shoes and hurries out after him.
It's just around the bend.
This other girl and I were lucky to rent it.
It's a very fashionable district.
I'll get an extra one made for you.
This is Gorgette, my roommate.
Now you just get comfortable and I'll make you a Martini and see what's to cook for dinner.
It's better.
Replies.Didascalie: (over her shoulder as she exits to kitchen)

Replies.Reply: You're a very good dancer.
That's nice. Because I love you, too.
I'm glad. Because I need you, too.
You're a funny one, little Prew boy.
A very funny one that I cannot figure out.
Because I'm a girl you met at the New Congress Club! And that's about two steps up from the pavement.
Oh, Prew, Prew, I thought we were happy: Why do you want to spoil things?
Now I know you've lost your mind!
All right. It's not.
I won't marry you because I don't want to be the wife of a soldier.
Because nobody's going to stop me from my plan. Nobody. Nothing.
Yes, proper. Respectable. Secure.
Prew!
Here it is -- they're putting it on an inside page already.
Did you hear me? Are you listening or not?
Are you trying to set a new world's record?
I want to know what you plan to do.
Any time. Now. Tomorrow. Next week.

It's December sixth and you're so drunk you're wall-eyed. And all you've done since you fell in here is drink and drink and drink and try to remember that old song of yours. And I want to know what you're going to do!
Oh, be sensible!
Oh, Prew! Prew! Why did you have to do it? Why did you have to kill that man?
What Germans?!
We've been at Queens Hospital --
The Post? Tonight?
But why?
But you can't! You're not fit yet --
And they'll find out it was you who killed that soldier!
But you'll never make it! There's MPs all over --
Stay till morning!
What do you want to go back to the Army for?! What did the Army ever do for you? Besides treat you like scum and give you one awful going over and get your friend killed?
A soldier! A soldier! A Regular.
No one would know there was a war, from out here.
I won't come back. I had to get away from here. You see, my fiance was killed on December seventh.
He was a bomber pilot. He tried to taxi his plane off the apron and the Japs made a direct hit on it.
They're very fine people. Southern people. He was named after a General. Robert E. Lee -- Prewitt.
Robert E. Lee Prewitt.
Isn't that a silly old name?

Characters.Character: MEDIUM SHOT AT BAR FEATURING MAGGIO

Replies.Reply: Maggio talks across others at the bar to Prew and Alma.
finishing a long gulp of beer. He puts glass down on the bar, hard.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT PREW AND ALMA

Replies.Reply: Prew is increasingly concerned for Maggio.
as Prew watches Maggio rush out. He sees something else o.s, which worries him.
Alma follows Prew's troubled look.
Maggio is stretched out on the bench, seems to be sleeping blissfully. He is clothed only in his shorts. Despite himself, Prew smiles. He shakes the reclining figure.
Prew whispers to Maggio as he pulls him to his feet.
The two MPs are on the street just outside the grounds. They are still looking for Maggio, somewhat aimlessly now.
Maggio picks up his shoes, suddenly whips away from Prew and runs toward the MPs.
Club gone, his partner on the ground, the second UP fishes for his pistol, tugs to get it from the holster.

Warden is pinning some notices on a bulletin board. Prew sits on the bench against the wall, miserable, elbows on knees, chin in hand. There is a quiet tenseness in the room. Warden looks over at Prew, turns back to the bulletin board.
Maggio sits between the driver and another MP, both armed.
Shut up!
Yeah. Theys the creepy ones. Walkin around just like ordinary civilians. I betcha they operatin all over these islands.
You heard him say SHUT UP!
I ain't worried about them.
as the Reconnaissance car drives through the chain-mesh gate.
his eyes following a movement of Fatso's hand.
Eyes on Maggio, his hand gropes on the desk.

Characters.Character: LONG SHOT THROUGH BONFIRE HULA DANCERS

Replies.Reply: A group of male dancers swaying with the insistent beat of a group of old Hawaiian instruments. This is far removed from the night club Hula. This is a thing of swift, agile angularity, primitive and powerful.
her face lit by the flames. She watches the dancing breathlessly.
astonished and thrilled at Warden's ability.
The men laugh and grin as they dance, taunt and tease somebody o.s.
They shout and laugh and squeal with delight as they watch.
nodding, pointing at Warden, their hilarious laughter fading to delighted smiles.
FEATURING the non-"ath-a-leets" of G Company, including Anderson, Clark and Treadwell. Ad-libbed shouts of "In the face, Prew! In the face!"
They are all laughing as they dance, but as Warden moves with them it is apparent he is as good as any of them.

Characters.Character: GROUP SHOT FEATURING KAREN AND WARDEN

Replies.Reply: as the spectators and dancers shout their applause. Warden comes up to Karen and puts the gardenia in her hair. Karen is glowing, tingling.
SHOOTING DOWN a thousand feet into Palolo Valley. Bonfires and smoke rising from the floor of the valley.
holding hands as they walk.
Don't mind me. I'm going out in a little while.
I belong to the Book of the Month Club. I always take every book.
It's the Japs. The Japs!
The town's a madhouse. Trucks, busses, jeeps all over --
And the drugstore on McKully and King is smashed flat. And the man and his wife were killed --
Your side'll open up --

The abandoned gaiety of the earlier scene gone. They survey the emptiness. The fat Hawaiian woman comes near, rakes ashes over one of the dying fires. She speaks to Warden in Hawaiian. He answers her in the native tongue. The fat woman stares, shrugs, goes off.
looking through records for a new choice. She speaks quite conversationally, as if offered a pleasant compliment.
at breakfast in a nook off the kitchen. Holmes is a mixture of petulance, anger and frustration. He doesn't touch his food, but occasionally takes a sip of coffee.
Prew, on hands and knees, is on a weeding detail with three other men, one of them Sal Anderson. Another is PRIVATE NAIR, a tousle-headed, sentimental man we have not seen before.
It was rugged, sam. But I kept my mouth shut and watched my step and I wasn't in no trouble.

Fatso's workin him over with a hoe handle. Places where it won't show mostly. You know, the back and the chest. The kidneys. Once in a while in the face. Know what Maggio does when that happens? Spits in Fatso's eye.
Oh, he's a hot one. Ain't he a hot one?
Course, he throws up a little blood now and then. And he passes out a lot. But Fatso sure ain't reportin none of that. So there's no way they goin to find out.
We tried to get him to. But he won't peep. He says he got a lot more scalp to lose first. That boy is about the hardest artery in the hospital.
But he's got a heart just like a great big baby.
Your guess is worth mine, sam.
The head, Prew! Hit him in the head!
Say! This'll make me a good souvenir! A bullet from a Jap plane!
Prew shoves Thornhill aside, cold decision in his eyes. He starts unbuttoning his shirt.
puzzled by Prew's concentration on his body and by the shouts of the men. He seems to be wondering if Prew is pulling a trick.
flinching without being hit. He seems mesmerized by the other's eyes.
His eyes narrow, harden as if his inner struggle has been resolved.
fighting. Galovitch draws blood from a cut over Prew's eye.
as Galovitch batters Prew back against the crowd. A right to the temple sends him to his knees. He shakes his head a moment, gets up and goes into a clinch.
The fight continuing.

Prew, backed up against the crowd, trips over somebody's feet. He falls without being hit. Galovitch kicks at him and Prew rolls away. The crowd murmurs angrily. Sergeant Stark steps out into the open circle, faces Galovitch.
Prew gets to his feet. As Galovitch comes to him, Prew feints for the stomach, then throws a hard right to Galovitch's face. It hits him flush on the nose. Blood spurts. The crowd roars.
The whole nature of the fight has changed. Galovitch, hurt and reeling, rushes Prew, bull-like, head down, defense wide open. Prew dodges easily, slamming hard with rights and lefts to the head.
I don't get it -- Why don't Prew go for the head?

Characters.Character: SHOT WARDEN AND HOLMES FEATURING WARDEN

Replies.Reply: Warden is at his desk filling out an application blank.
Still near the rear of the crowd, he watches the scene with much interest.
It's your show, kid. Run it the way you want.
as Prew crosses. He can see the seated figure but the light from the street is too dim to identify it.
Halt!

as he stumbles around the side of the jeep directly into the blaze of the headlights. There are scars, new and healing on Maggio's face. One of his ears is cauliflowered, enough to give him the lopsided ribald look of a punchy. A couple of teeth are missing. Weirdly outlined in the glare, he is a nightmare figure, an apparition. The whine in the distance is identifiable now. It is the siren of the Stockade.

The men gape at Maggio, unable to accept the shock of his appearance. Then Prew and Warden jump up and catch him as he is about to fall. The drunkenness drains out of them. Stark watches in bewilderment.
Warden bends over Maggio. The others watch, scared.
Warden looks up.
as he listens. A look of mingled longing and satisfaction.
listening. A strange look of pride.
listening, his face also betraying emotions normally concealed.
listening. Their bunks are next to each other.
lying on his back in his bunk, arms clasped behind his head.
There is a choked kinship on all the faces.
as the Taps repeat is drawing to a close. He is lying on his side, turned toward the Bugler, a look of serenity, of peace on his face. His eyes close as he falls asleep.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT PREW AND CLARK

Replies.Reply: Prew lowers the bugle slowly and lets the megaphone rest in its swivel. He withdraws the mouthpiece, puts it in his pocket. He hands the bugle to Clark. Clark looks at the instrument as if it has become hallowed. Prew walks off into the darkness.
Just enough light from the street lamp to illuminate about ten feet into the alley.
as the figure comes directly to camera, REVEALING the anguished face of Fatso. It slowly turns, is upside down in the frame.
The radio is blaring the "Hut Sut Song." Alma is crocheting.
She rushes to him, bends over him. Gorgette runs to the radio, turns it off.
Her face agonized as she leans over Prew.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT ALMA AND PREW

Replies.Reply: He pushes himself up on one elbow, seems pleased by her stricken expression. He manages a smile.
--- In addition to inefficiency in administering his command and neglect of duty, Captain Holmes has been guilty of indefensible cruelty to the aforesaid Private Prewitt.
He confronts her, waving a sheet of stationery. His voice is strangled, almost hysterical.
reacting; she is surprised, a little afraid of her own emotion. The outcry, so lost, so despairing, moves her. She is sorry for him.
-- I don't intend to have a sloppy outfit. I don't intend to have a goldbrick outfit. I don't intend to have a soft soap outfit. I've called you noncoms in because you're the backbone of any Company.
From now on you'll have to prove you're entitled to have those stripes here. And not in the boxing ring.
Get rid of these, Sergeant.
That's all I have to say. If you've any questions, speak up.
Dismissed.
I know. Private Galovitch is in the kitchen.
As of now, he's an assistant cook.
HERE COMES A JAP!
Alma is reading a newspaper in b.g. Prew is disheveled and slovenly, needs a shave badly. His face is lined with pain.
A man sprints toward the mess hall, yelling to right and left at the top of his lungs. As he approaches camera we see it is Mazzioli.
as the Jap plane flashes by close above him. The stones in the pavement pop up. Mazzioli flops on the street. The plane zooms.

Characters.Character: LONG SHOT SHOOTING UP TO SKY

Replies.Reply: A pair of planes are diving toward the street.
They flatten against the wall as a Jap plane roars building-
What's the deal, First?
In b.g. Henderson and others are going up the porch stairs to the roof. They tote BARs and loading clips. Karelsen and two helpers follow with a heavy machine gun and belt boxes.
About twenty of Company GIs men, including almost all the non-
The men fire in unison. They rise after the planes pass, shake their fists. Henderson and others of the loading detail appear on the roof, bringing up more ammunition.
He lets out a hoarse yell of glee and pride. "These are my boys. This is my Company," it seems to say. The men answer back with a great answering shout.
Treadwell turns, yells at the men.
His cheeks puffed, blowing the bugle madly.

Lieutenant Ross is hailed by the loading detail -- about ten men. He grabs a BAR and ammunition from them and runs into the barracks. The loading detail is working feverishly, same carrying ammunition into the barracks, others picking up empty clips as they are thrown from the roof and hustling them toward the Supply Room.
He is working hard, passing out ammunition to members of the loading detail. But he shakes his head dourly as if the whole thing is still very unofficial.

Characters.Character: TWO SHOT LIEUTENANT ROSS AND WARDEN

Replies.Reply: Ross looks around the roof, nods with evident approval, claps Warden on the shoulder.
firing a BAR at the planes.
firing.
firing Joyously.
singing as he fires.

firing the machine gun. He yanks the tripod away from his helpers, picks up the gun, stands and swings it after the plane. The recoil staggers him half way across the roof and deposits him on his rear.
He jumps in his seat like a man tied to a hot stove, throws up his arms helplessly.
The men rise as one with an uproarious cheer. They rush to Karelsen, pick him up. Warden lets go with another of his rebel yells.

Characters.Character: SHOT SHOOTING FROM ROOF JAP PLANE

Replies.Reply: swooping across the quadrangle about ten feet from the ground.
It misses the roof by a foot or two, zooms up at a weird angle. A thick cloud of smoke pours out of the engine. The plane falls off on one wing and crashes into trees at the end of the quadrangle.
crashing. The gas-tank explodes. A cloud of fire and black 150.
Stockade. They need every man they can get.
He puts the folded piece of paper in his pocket and starts for the door.
They say they seen parachutists land up in the mountains.

Characters.Character: LONG SHOT OPPOSITE SIDE OF ROAD

Replies.Reply: visible, bent low, weaving a little. As he approaches the camera, he is taught square in the twin beams of dimmed headlights which flash on from the side of the road. Now we see that a jeep is parked near camera, heading in the opposite direction from the jeep which passed before. It is also manned by three MPs. There is a startled cry from Prew.
The motor starts, The jeep moves out from its hiding place and starts across the golf course.

Prew, in a skirmisher's zigzag, is trying to elude the spotlight. He is about twenty yards in front of the jeep. He heads for a high sandtrap. The spot is full on him as he reaches the lip of the trap. He turns, yells something back at the jeep. It is barely heard over the sound of the jeep.
There is no sound as the screen remains black for several beats.
Where's your Company Commander?
Did you know this man personally?
He didn't have any regular identification. But they found a card on him with his name --
-- seems to be a membership in a club. The -- New Congress Club.
I'll turn this over to you. And these other things that were on him. This --
And this. Whatever it is.
Are you all right, Sergeant? Was this man a friend of yours?
I believe I can attend to that for you.
I'm sorry, Sergeant.

Characters.Character: MEDIUM SHOT WARDEN AND LIEUTENANT COLONEL

Replies.Reply: They are standing on the lip of the sandtrap. The hoods of the jeeps that chased Prew and the second jeep are just behind them in shot.
She is looking back at the city. Around her neck is a garland of leis.
They are floating on the water behind the ship. They are being carried out to sea.
A choppy wave washes over it, submerges it.
